questions.question: All sorting algorithms produce the same order of steps, only their runtimes differ.
What are the four sorting algorithms discussed in the slides?
questions.answer: Insertion Sort, Selection Sort, Merge Sort, Quick Sort

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the purpose of sorting algorithms?
options: A) To organize data for easier searching

questions.question: In insertion sort, how is the array conceptually divided during sorting?
questions.answer: It is divided into a sorted part and an unsorted part.

questions.question: In insertion sort, the 'key' element is always compared to the right-most element first.
In insertion sort, what happens when the left-most element is greater than the key?
options: A) The key replaces that element
B) The larger element is shifted right
C) The algorithm skips to the next iteration

questions.question: Write the condition inside the while loop that keeps moving elements in insertion sort.
How does selection sort find the correct element to place in the sorted part each iteration?
questions.answer: It finds the smallest element in the unsorted part and swaps it with the first unsorted element.

questions.question: What variable name is typically used to track the lowest value during selection sort?
In selection sort, each iteration moves the largest remaining value to the end of the array.
What is the purpose of the swap() function in selection sort?
questions.answer: It exchanges the positions of the current index and the found minimum value.

questions.question: Merge sort uses what strategy to break down and solve problems?
Which of the following is NOT a key step in merge sort?
Why does merge sort require an auxiliary array?
questions.answer: It temporarily stores merged results while combining sorted halves.

questions.question: Merge sort can operate entirely in-place without any additional memory.
What happens after both halves of an array are sorted in merge sort?
questions.answer: They are merged together into a single sorted array.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of the pivot element in quicksort?
questions.answer: To divide the array into two sublists — one with smaller values and one with larger values.

questions.question: What is the worst-case time complexity of quicksort?
Why does always choosing the left-most element as the pivot cause O(n²) behavior on sorted arrays?
questions.answer: Because the partitions become unbalanced, causing many unnecessary recursive calls.

questions.question: Quicksort performs poorly on arrays with many repeated elements.
